PM11:06am

As political crisis deepens, risk of snap elections returns

Following the recent escalation of political tensions in Italy, the main risk associated with a return to polls in the near term, in addition to continuation of the current political paralysis, is escalation of electoral rhetoric against the EU. In that regard, we think it will be critical to assess which electoral strategy 5SM and L decide to follow ahead of the next ballot.

Manxish Morning all
PM11:06am

Conte returns his mandate, over to Cottarelli

Professor Giuseppe Conte, Italy's designated Prime Minister, on Sunday returned his mandate to form a government comprised of anti-establishment forces 5SM and the League (L).

President Mattarella rejected nominee Paolo Savona for the role of Finance Minister due to his anti-European stance, while PM-in-waiting Conte did not suggest an alternative candidate.

In a brief speech held after meeting Mr Conte, President Mattarella said he did whatever he could to facilitate the formation of a government between 5SM and L, including accepting every cabinet candidate except for the Finance Minister role.

For such a critical job, President Mattarella said he asked for the nomination of a person belonging to the political majority supporting the government who would not be perceived as supporting an anti-European stance. Such a hostile approach, he said, could be responsible for Italy exiting the euro, a scenario that did not take centre stage during the electoral campaign, he added.

President Mattarella summoned Carlo Cottarelli, former head of the IMF’s fiscal affairs department and Italy's spending review commissioner, to his office on Monday morning to discuss the formation of a government. At the end of the meeting, Mr Cottarelli accepted, with reservations, the task of forming a government.

In a brief speech held after meeting with President Mattarella, PM-in-waiting Cottarelli said his government, if appointed to Parliament, would approve the budget and take the country to new elections at the beginning of next year. Should the caretaker government fail to win a confidence vote, Cottarelli said snap elections would be held shortly, after the month of August. Finally, Cottarelli said neither he nor members of his government would run in the next elections. A confidence vote could be held in both Chambers by the end of this week.

BornCynic Morning
SoS sorry grouch = hit it before I saw yours

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Snap elections increasingly likely, once again

Unless either the 5SM or L parties decide to support the formation of a non-partisan government endorsed by President Mattarella (unlikely, based on declarations by senior 5SM and L members on Sky TV on 28 May), a government led by Carlo Cottarelli would not be appointed by Parliament. In such a scenario, PM-appointed-Cottarelli would remain in office until a new government is sworn in.

Therefore, snap elections this year look likely again, as we discussed after the failure of a third round of talks to form a government (see Italian politics: Fresh elections likely, old risks certain, 7 May 2018).

Excel Developer Italy Central Bank Banca d'Italia had an annual report out today with a presser, that probably didn;t help the poltical crisis either.
PM11:07am

When could snap elections be held?

We believe that President Mattarella will refrain from dissolving the Parliament before the EU summit of 28 June, at which the European leaders will have to discuss important issues for the future of Europe.

Given elections must be held between 45 (more realistically 60, for technical reasons) and 70 days after the end of the legislature, the earliest snap elections could realistically be held is the first half of September.

Paper Chase Hullo.
PM11:07am

What to watch

Assuming the current Rosatellum voting system - see Euro Themes - Italy: In search of governability, 27 September 2017 - stays the same, it will be critical to watch whether the most important political forces decide to run for elections according to the same tactical pre electoral strategies followed ahead of the 4 March ballot.

In particular, the decision of L would be particularly important as it could influence the overall rhetoric and potentially the significance of the next electoral appointment in Italy.

We think L has to decide between three options:

1) Rejoining a centre right alliance with Forza Italia (FI) led by Silvio Berlusconi and Fratelli di Italia (FdI) led by Giorgia Meloni;

2) Entering a coalition/non-aggression pact with 5SM;

3) Running independently.

Grouchmonkey @SoS snap!
11:07 am
PM11:08am

Option 3 looks the least probable, based on the numbers. Despite having experienced a notable boost of about +8pp to 25.4% since 4 March according to the latest polls (Corriere della Sera, 18 May 2018), L would not be able to challenge 5SM’s lead (32.6%, according to the same polls).

Therefore, options 1 and 2 are the most likely to unfold, in our view, but it is very difficult to say which path L is likely to follow.‎ At this stage, rejoining a centre right coalition would appear slightly more likely, for the following reasons:

PM11:08am

1) In a centre right coalition, Salvini would probably be a candidate for Prime Minister and have a decent chance of being appointed (and very likely a higher chance than he had ahead of the 4 March elections). According to simulations provided by Youtrend, a party or a coalition would be able to secure an outright majority in both Chambers if it manages to secure about 41-42% of the total vote. According to the latest polls, a centre right coalition would be able to win 39.5% of the vote if elections were to be held today, 2.5pp more than it achieved on 4 March.

2) Salvini refrained from joining the intention 5SM and FdI declared to begin impeachment proceedings against President Mattarella for his decision to reject nominee Savona for the role of Finance Minister. While Salvini’s rhetoric escalated after Mattarella’s speech last night, it was directed more toward European institutions and partners than President Mattarella explicitly. This seems to suggest that Salvini might pursue a different communications strategy from other anti-establishment parties.

3) Salvini reportedly (La Repubblica, 28 May) asked Forza Italia not to back a Cottarelli government, ‎or the centre right alliance would be in danger.

4) It is unclear at this stage whether 5SM would be willing to form a pre-electoral alliance/non-aggression plan with L. That will very much depend on who will be heading 5SM—whether it will still be current leader Luigi Di Maio or somebody else more left leaning such as Alessandro Di Battista, perhaps.

Grouchmonkey Thought the market was rather hard on Dixons Carphone results. What did they expect? Anyway glad I sold last week.
PM11:08am

Last one I promise!

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Shifting allegiances, shifting rhetoric?

Whether L and 5SM decide to join forces ahead of the next election is likely to heavily influence the rhetoric of the electoral campaign and potentially the significance of the next electoral appointment in Italy, and with that, market sentiment.

If the two anti-establishment forces were to team up, they might decide to adopt an explicitly anti-European stance, possibly even more forceful than the one held since the electoral campaign started in January.

Meanwhile, if they decide to run separately, we think that outright anti-European rhetoric would be less likely to dominate the communications strategy of the centre right alliance, due to the presence within that alliance of a pro-EU party such as Forza Italia. In such a scenario, the communications strategy of 5SM may depend on whether it continues to focus on internal or external political issues.

BE11:14am

The fact that President Matterella justified the unprecedented decision to veto the appointment of Mr Savona by stressing the importance of Italy’s euro membership to preserve Italians’ savings and wealth makes it very likely that the next snap election will be fought with a very sharp divide between pro and anti-EU arguments, possibly transforming the ballot to something similar to a referendum on the euro. Note that support for the euro among Italians is just above 50%. Markets are likely to remain under pressure for some time, and the main near-term risk is one of further contagion to some of the less fiscally robust government debt markets of the periphery, and more broadly on business confidence. The obvious medium-term casualty will be the euro area reform process, whereby a number of governments will be reluctant to engage in a genuinely stabilising reform process if Italy were to reverse some of its structural reforms. We also very much doubt that the ECB can or should act as a backstop in the near term.

The c.£80m yoy reduction is driven by -£5m due to removal of the non-operational items (debtor book reval and trade balance reconciliation), a -£8m negative impact from IFRS15 implementation, -£15m due to lower RPI income growth on mobile, -£30m of cost investment and a further c.-£24m due to further contraction of UK electricals and mobile market.

BE11:29am

Dixons Carphone has a very strong market position in both the UK and Northern Europe, and has been gaining share in electricals, albeit with some margin pressure due to channel and mix shift.

Its smaller mobile business is still facing challenging industry headwinds but we expect DC to manage the cost base down and lower its working capital intensity over time.

DC should also benefit from further cost savings in the UK (e.g., lower rents) and from new warehousing in the Nordic area.

Valuation is undemanding with a CY18 P/E of c.9x and a 6% dividend yield, albeit with a lower level of earnings visibility and transparency than some other companies in the sector.

BE11:36am

The Japanese group's c.$100bn Vision Fund, backed by Middle Eastern and US investors, targets investments in disruptive innovators in the
technology sector. To date the funds largest investments include Uber, ARM Holdings, and a $4.4bn investment in WeWork in August 2017, valuing the group at $20bn. If the fund is willing to invest in WeWork then why not IWG? WeWork's recent bond prospectus highlighted the similarities of the operating models, although IWG generated £376m of EBITDA in 2017 vs c.-£570m for WeWork on the same basis. Acquiring IWG would provide SoftBank with global leadership in the flexible workspace market, and a business
already generating profits and cash flow. It would also enhance the fund's exposure to the secular growth in co-working, which is increasingly being embraced by corporates, through both the WeWork and Spaces brands.

In this note we further consider the perspectives of both the IWG board and PE, re-enforcing our belief that a take-out bid of up to 370p is possible, and potentially higher if the stars truly align.

Ocado has so far only opened one warehouse on the new technology and after recent deals it has commitments for 24. Ocado will need to work out how to manufacture the robots in time and have the right resources to carry out the installation and training. It will need to have the appropriate software to cater to the different partners in the different countries. Execution issues could lead to higher than expected cash outflows and weight on the shares.

BE11:51am

We combine detailed cost analysis with local labor estimates and population to determine the potential future contracts. We estimate there are only 9 additional developed countries where the solution at the current cost might make sense. Whilst the Kroger endorsement could drive additional sales, with each £1bn worth of capacity worth c.30p, we do not see additional contract signings driving material upside. We now incorporate greater value for signed contracts but no longer incorporate value for future contracts in our base case (takes off c.40p from our price target).
